scenarioDescription:
The HIP 65407 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HIP 65407 is a star with 0.93 times the mass of the Sun, and NaN times its radius. It is located 201.50 light years away from the solar system.

HIP 65407 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HIP 65407 system


HIP 65407 b

HIP 65407 b was discovered by the Haute-Provence Observatory observatory, in 2016-04, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.18 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 65407 b is 136.104 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 65407 b is 14.300 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HIP 65407 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HIP 65407 c

HIP 65407 c was discovered by the Haute-Provence Observatory observatory, in 2016-04, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.32 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 65407 c is 249.312 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 65407 c is 13.900 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HIP 65407 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system HIP 65407, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Haute-Provence Observatory.
name: HIP 65407 - System With 2 Exoplanets
